course_title: Foundations in Politics, Policy and International Relations

learning_outcomes.description: Demonstrate a well-founded knowledge of the key ideas and issues in the field of politics.
Demonstrate acquired conceptual and analytical capacities, along with an ability to apply these skills to understand concrete social, political and historical processes in politics.
Develop intellectual tools and skills that will make you more competitive in your future professional activities in a variety of fields and positions.

assessments.task_description:
Active engagement with the teaching activities and course materials is an essential part of studying POLS7002. Participation is not just about making smart comments or getting answers to questions right. It is also about airing ideas, asking questions, participating in small group discussions, and contributing to a productive classroom discussion.

In the final class of the semester, students will participate in a poster session presenting their essay. In addition to being stationed at your poster discussing your research and answering questions, students will have the opportunity to mingle and learn about other students’ research.

assessments.task_description:
Students will write a 3,000 word essay on a topic of their choice. It is expected that students will make some sort of original research contribution. Emphasis should be on assessing relevant literature, identifying a gap in the literature, and how your research fills this gap. Further details and examples will be provided in class throughout the semester.

Artificial Intelligence (AI) and Machine Translation (MT) are emerging tools that may support students in completing this assessment task. Students may appropriately use AI and/or MT in completing this assessment task. Students must clearly reference any use of AI or MT in each instance.

A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.

In this introductory seminar we will discuss some of the fundamental building blocks of what makes something political.

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03

learning_activities.topic:
Realism

The next three seminars will examine some traditions/schools of thought in International Relations. This week we will introduce Realism and the role that anarchy plays in the thinking of Realist scholars in International Relations.
